channel.title: Coupons?
channel.description:
So, I just came back from Shoprite (a grocery store in USA, mainly CT, NJ, NY, etc.) and "bought" over $100 of merchandise (including a $50 Visa card) for 78 cents out of pocket money, and ended up earning ~$70 in checkout coupons that I can use on anything. So basically, I got free food, a $50 Visa card I can spend on anything, and made $70 that I can use on anything next week in the store.
Note: I've probably gotten over $1000 worth of groceries, etc for around $5 out of pocket money and have probably made over $200.
inb4prooforgtfo inb4imnotpoor
I don't need proof. If you don't believe me, don't post and keep to yourself.
Is couponing worth it? Discuss.

item.title: Coupons?
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

My mom used to cut and get coupons all the time. Usually when we buy a month of groceries, she’d take her envelope of coupons and we’d end up saving enough money to pay for the next month. That kind of money can go towards gas money, games, computer parts or even if you keep saving, car parts (though, that’d be a long time). I don’t see why people wouldn’t use coupons.

Read full topic

item.title: Coupons?
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

Coupons?

Yes, the 78 cents was basically tax. Let’s say an item was $1.50 and I had a coupon for 75 cents off. My store doubles coupons, so I receive the item for free. In other cases, there’s a “Buy $20 worth of X products and get a $10 checkout coupon off your next shopping trip.” The $20 that needs to be spent is always before coupons are used and are usually based on shelf (non-sale) prices, so if I use a $3 off coupon on a detergent that is $5 sale price, but $8.50 shelf price, $8.50 would count towards the $20 rather than the $2 I actually paid for it. When I reach the $20 mark, I usually end up paying $5, which I pay using a previous $5 off coupon from last week and receive a $10 checkout coupon for next week or anytime before the expiry date. Thus, I pay nothing out of pocket and “earn” $5. There’s also many times where I pay nothing and get $x in checkout coupons making the deal a x-dollar moneymaker. Sounds too good to be true, but it is.

Read full topic

item.title: Coupons?
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

He’s certainly not lying.

Gimundo: The Brighter Side

How to Feed Your Family on $4 a Week | Gimundo: The Brighter Side

In this video for Good Morning, America, a mother shares her secrets for buying a week's worth of meals for just $4.

We can’t do this in the UK. Our businesses seem to have a little more sense and only let you use 1 coupon per visit.

Also if you start saying “oh, by the way can I also…” CASHIER “NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!”.

item.title: Coupons?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Coupons are awesome, when I was a cashier at Meijers (a large grocery chain/super store around my area, think Super-Walmart), sometimes people would buy hundreds of dollars of food/items and pay just a few dollars, it’s hard to do, but combined with sales sometimes you can get really really good deals.

I myself can remember 2 really good deals I got while working there:

  1. Dr. Pepper Red Fusion came out in 2 liter bottles, and they had 50cent off coupons on them, the bottles were 99 cents and Meijers doubles coupons, so they were free and I just had to pay 7 cents tax on each bottle. I ended up buying all they had with coupons which totaled about 52 bottles for something around $2 dollars, the hardest part was fitting them in the small cab of my 1982 Dodge Rampage pickup.
  2. They had a corporate sale on ceiling fans, and the regular sale ad had a $15 dollar off coupon, and there was an additional discount, combined with my 10% off for working there. In the end, I bought 55 fans for pennies, sometimes they even paid me to take them. I went around to all the Meijers that I could drive to and bought all the fans, ended up with about 30 of them that I paid around $5 total for, I sold them for $25 each at a garage sale and ended up with a net profit of about $700 bucks. That was sweet!

Read full topic
